revision.text:
{{Life in the African Union}}
The '''languages of the [[African Union]]''' are [[language]]s used by citizens within the [[member states of the African Union]] (AU). For languages of the institution, see [[African Union#Languages|African Union: Languages]].
==Overview== The African Union has defined a number of languages as working languages including [[Arabic language|Arabic]], [[English language|English]], [[French language|French]] and [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]] as well as [[Languages of Africa|African languages]] if possible.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.au.int/en/sites/default/files/ConstitutiveAct_EN.pdf |title=Constitutive Act of the African Union |publisher=African Union |format=PDF |accessdate=4 November 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130706133134/http://www.au.int/en/sites/default/files/ConstitutiveAct_EN.pdf |archivedate=6 July 2013 |df= }}</ref> The prominence of Arabic in many African countries is due to the [[Muslim conquest of the Maghreb|Arab expansion into Africa]] from the 7th century, with subsequent [[Arabization]] of local populations. [[Indo-European languages]] were introduced during the [[Colonisation of Africa|European colonisation]] from the 15th century.
In 2001, the AU created the [[African Academy of Languages]] (ACALAN) to [[Language policy|harmonize the various languages]] across the continent and [[Language revival|safeguard]] any that are on the verge of becoming [[extinct language|extinct]]. To that end, the AU declared 2006 the Year of African Languages.<ref name="Year of African Languages">{{cite web |url=http://allafrica.com/stories/200606210733.html |title=Ethiopia: AU Launches 2006 As Year of African Languages |accessdate=2006-09-30 |year=2006 |publisher=AllAfrica.com }}</ref><ref name="Year of African Languages 2">{{cite web |url=http://web.uct.ac.za/depts/praesa/YoAL.htm |title=The Year of African Languages (2006) - Plan for the year of African Languages - Executive Summary |accessdate=2006-09-30 |author=Project for the Study of Alternative Education in South Africa |year=2006 |publisher=Project for the Study of Alternative Education in South Africa |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20060923084909/http://web.uct.ac.za/depts/praesa/YoAL.htm |archivedate=2006-09-23 |df= }}</ref> 2006 also marked Ghana's 55th anniversary since it founded the [[Bureau of Ghana Languages]] originally known as [[Bureau of Ghana Languages|Gold Coast Vernacular Literature Bureau]].
==Languages of AU states== *{{DZA}} – The [[Constitution of Algeria]] defines the [[official language|official languages]] as [[Arabic language|Arabic]] and [[Berber languages|Berber]]. French is spoken by governmental and educational elite. There is also an [[Algerian Sign Language]]. ([[Languages of Algeria]]) *{{AGO}} – Portuguese is the [[official language]], and many people speak one or several of 41 [[Bantu languages|Bantu]] or [[Khoisan languages]]. ([[Languages of Angola]]) *{{BEN}} – French is the [[official language]], with [[Fon language|Fon]] and [[Yoruba language|Yoruba]] being the most common languages in the south. At least six major languages are spoken in the north. ([[Languages of Benin]]) *{{BWA}} – English and Tswana are the [[official language]]s, with [[Tswana language|Tswana]] being the most common [[national language]]. There are significant communities that speak [[Ikalanga language|Ikalanga]] and [[Sekgalagadi language|Sekgalagadi]]. ([[Languages of Botswana]]) *{{BFA}} – French is the [[official language]]. [[Mossi language|Mossi]], [[Dyula language|Dyula]] and [[Fula language|Fula]] are the [[national language]]s. Most speak one of the [[Sudanic languages]]. ([[Languages of Burkina Faso]]) *{{BDI}} – French and [[Kirundi]] are co-official. Many persons also speak Swahili. ([[Languages of Burundi]]) *{{CMR}} – English and French are co-official, with [[Cameroonian Pidgin English]] widely spoken. Twenty-four major African language families and sub-groups are present in Cameroon. Cameroon is one of the most linguistically diverse areas in the world. ([[Languages of Cameroon]]) *{{CPV}} – Standard Portuguese is official along with [[Portuguese Creole|nine creoles]]. ([[Languages of Cape Verde]]) *{{CAF}} – French and [[Sango language|Sango]] are co-official; the former is the lingua franca. Sango is the local language with the most speakers, 70 languages are listed in the Ethnologue report for the country. ([[Languages of the Central African Republic]]) *{{TCD}} – Arabic and French are co-official, with over 120 other languages spoken. ([[Languages of Chad]]) *{{COM}} – Arabic, French, and [[Comorian language|Comorian]] are co-official; the latter is a [[Swahili language|Swahili]] dialect, albeit heavily influenced by [[Arabic]] and [[French language|French]]. ([[Languages of Comoros]]) *{{COD}} – French is official, with four [[national language]]s: [[Kongo language|Kikongo]], [[Lingala language|Lingala]], Swahili, and [[Tshiluba language|Tshiluba]]. There are an estimated total of 242 languages spoken in the DRC. ([[Languages of the Democratic Republic of the Congo]]) *{{COG}} – French is official, but is only spoken by the cultural elite. [[Lingala]] and [[Kituba]] are national linguae francae; the latter is a [[creole language|creole]] of Kikongo. ([[Languages of the Republic of the Congo]]) *{{CIV}} – French is official, with some 60 indigenous languages, of which the Dioula dialect of [[Bambara language|Bambara]] is the most widely spoken. Other languages include: the [[Gur languages]], the [[Kru languages]] (including the [[Bété languages]], [[Dida language|Dida]], [[Nyabwa language|Nyabwa]], [[Wè language|Wè]], and [[Western Krahn]]), and the [[Kwa languages]]. ([[Languages of Côte d'Ivoire]]) *{{DJI}} – Arabic and French are co-official; [[Afar language|Afar]] and [[Somali language|Somali]] are widely spoken. ([[Languages of Djibouti]]) *{{EGY}} – Arabic is official, with [[Egyptian Arabic]] being the most common spoken language. English and French are major languages for education and trade. See [[languages of Egypt]] *{{GNQ}} – [[Spanish language|Spanish]], French and Portuguese are official. Other languages include [[Annobonese language|Annobonese]], [[Bubi language|Bubi]], [[Beti-Pahuin#Fang|Fang]], [[Igbo language|Igbo]], and [[Pichinglis]]. ([[Languages of Equatorial Guinea]]) *{{ERI}} – There is no [[official language]] per se, but Arabic, English, Italian and [[Tigrinya language|Tigrinya]] are used by the government. Other common languages include [[Afar language|Afar]], [[Blin language|Blin]], [[Kunama language|Kunama]], [[Nara language|Nara]], [[Saho language|Saho]], and [[Tigre language|Tigre]]. [[Ge'ez language|Ge'ez]] is the [[Sacred language|liturgical language]] of the [[Eritrean Orthodox Tewahdo Church]]. ([[Languages of Eritrea]]) *{{ETH}} – Amharic is official, among more than 80 languages spoken. English is widely spoken and taught in secondary school. ([[Languages of Ethiopia]]) *{{GAB}} – French is official, and many African languages are spoken. ([[Languages of Gabon]]) *{{GMB}} – English is official, and many African languages are also spoken, notably [[Wolof language|Wolof]]. ([[Languages of The Gambia]]) *{{GHA}} – English is official, [[Akan language|Akan]], [[Dagaare]]/Wale, [[Dagbane]], [[Dangme]], [[Ewe language|Ewe]], [[Ga language|Ga]], [[Gonja language|Gonja]], [[Kasem language|Kasem]] and [[Nzema language|Nzema]] are government-recognized languages sponsored by the [[Bureau of Ghana Languages]]. ([[Languages of Ghana]]) *{{GIN}} – French is official, [[Fula language|Fula]] ([[Pular language|Pular]]), [[Mandinka language|Mandinka]] and [[Susu language|Susu]] is the lingua franca. ([[Languages of Guinea]]) *{{GNB}} – Portuguese is official, but the most widely spoken language is a [[Portuguese-based creole language]], [[Upper Guinea Kriol language|Kriol]]. ([[Languages of Guinea-Bissau]]) *{{KEN}} – [[Swahili language|Swahili]] and English are official, and many other African languages are also spoken. ([[Languages of Kenya]]) *{{LSO}} – [[Sesotho]] and English are official. ([[Languages of Lesotho]]) *{{LBR}} – English is official, many African languages are spoken. ([[Languages of Liberia]]) *{{LBY}} – Arabic is official, [[Tamazight]] is spoken by about 10% of the population. [[Italian language|Italian]] is understood by some older Libyans. ([[Languages of Libya]]) *{{MDG}} – [[Malagasy language|Malagasy]], French are official. ([[Languages of Madagascar]]) *{{MWI}} – [[Chichewa]] or [[Nyanja]] and English are official. ([[Languages of Malawi]]) *{{MLI}} – French is [[official language|official]], [[Bambara language|Bambara]] is the primary [[lingua franca]]. Of the 50 languages spoken, 13 are classified [[national language]]s, including Bambara, [[Fula language|Fula]] ({{lang-ff|Fulfulde}}), [[Songhai languages|Sonrai]], and [[Soninke language|Soninke]] ([[Languages of Mali]]) *{{MRT}} – [[Arabic]] is official; other languages spoken include: [[Pulaar]], [[Soninke language|Soninke]], and [[Wolof language|Wolof]]. ([[Languages of Mauritania]]). French is used by upper classes. *{{MUS}} – English is the ''de jure'' [[official language]] but French is more widely spoken, making it the ''de facto'' [[official language]]. The vernacular language is [[Mauritian Creole]] which derives from French. [[Tamil language|Tamil]], [[Hindi language|Hindi]] and other [[Languages of India|Indian languages]] are spoken by the Indian community. Arabic, Portuguese and a number of [[varieties of Chinese|Chinese varieties]] like [[Hakka Chinese|Hakka]] and [[Mandarin Chinese|Mandarin]] are also spoken by some. ([[Languages of Mauritius]]) *{{MAR}} – Arabic and Berber. French is also widely spoken. ([[Languages of Morocco]]) *{{MOZ}} – Portuguese is the [[official language]]. [[Makhuwa language|Makua]]<!--Isn't Makua a language/dialect cluster?-->, [[Sena language|Sena]], [[Ndau language|Ndau]], [[Xitsonga|Tsonga]] and Swahili are spoken by a sizable amount of the population. The educated often speak English as a second or third language. The Arab, Indian and Chinese communities speak their own languages. ([[Languages of Mozambique]]) *{{NAM}} – The [[official language]] is English. Half of all Namibians speak [[Oshiwambo]] (Ovambo) as their first language, whereas the most widely understood language is [[Afrikaans]]. Most Whites in Namibia speak Afrikaans or [[German language|German]] which were the [[official language]]s before independence. ([[Languages of Namibia]]) *{{NER}} – French is the [[official language]]. [[Hausa language|Hausa]], [[Djerma language|Djerma]], [[Tamazheq language (disambiguation)|Tamajaq]], [[Fulfulde]] are important African languages. ([[Languages of Niger]]) *{{NGA}} – English is the [[official language]], Hausa, [[Igbo language|Igbo]], [[Yoruba language|Yoruba]], [[Efik language|Efik]], [[Edo language|Edo]], [[Adamawa languages|Adamawa]], [[Fulfulde]], [[Idoma language|Idoma]], and Central [[Kanuri language|Kanuri]] are all widely spoken. 510 languages currently exist with native speakers in Nigeria. ([[Languages of Nigeria]]) *{{RWA}} – [[Kinyarwanda]], French, and English are [[official language]]s. Kinyarwanda is the mother tongue of the vast majority of the population. ([[Languages of Rwanda]]). French and English are only spoken by a minority, and Swahili is used as a vehicular language. *{{STP}} – Portuguese is the [[official language]], spoken by 95% of the population. Other languages include the Portuguese-based creoles [[Forro language|Forro]] (85%), [[Angolar]] (3%) and [[Principense]] (0.1%). ([[Languages of São Tomé and Príncipe]]) *{{SEN}} – French is the [[official language]], used regularly by a minority of Senegalese educated in a system styled upon the colonial-era schools of French origin. Most persons also speak their own ethnic language while, especially in Dakar, [[Wolof language|Wolof]] is the lingua franca. [[Pulaar]] is spoken by the [[Fula people|Fulas]] ({{lang-fr|Peul}}; {{lang-ff|Fulɓe}}) and [[Toucouleur people|Toucouleur]] ([[Halpulaar]]). Various Portuguese Creoles are spoken in Senegal by those from Guinea-Bissau and São Tomé and Príncipe. ([[Languages of Senegal]]) *{{SYC}} – English, French and [[Seychellois Creole]] are official. As Seychelles had no indigenous population, many languages are spoken by the various African, Chinese, European, and Indian peoples who colonized it. Seychellois Creole is the lingua franca between these groups. ([[Languages of Seychelles]]) *{{SLE}} – English is the [[official language]] but it is only understood by a minority. Most persons speak their ethnic language. ([[Languages of Sierra Leone]]) *{{SOM}} – [[Somali language|Somali]] and Arabic are official. Somali is the most spoken language. Other [[Afro-Asiatic languages]] are also spoken in some areas, such as [[Maay language|Maay]], [[Dabarre language|Dabarre]], and [[Tunni language|Tunni]]. In addition, some [[Niger–Congo languages|Niger–Congo]] languages are spoken by ethnic minorities in parts of the south, including [[Bravanese dialect|Chimwiini]] and [[Kibajuni dialect|Kibajuni]] (two variants of Swahili) as well as [[Zigula language|Mushunguli]]. English is also widely used and taught in schools. [[Italian language|Italian]] used to be a major language, but its influence significantly diminished following independence. ([[Languages of Somalia]]) *{{ZAF}} – South Africa has 11 [[official language]]s: [[Afrikaans]], [[English language|English]], [[Southern Ndebele language|Southern Ndebele]], [[Northern Sotho]], [[Sesotho]], [[Swati language|Swati]], [[Tsonga language|Tsonga]], [[Tswana language|Tswana]], [[Venda language|Venda]], [[Xhosa language|Xhosa]], and [[Zulu language|Zulu]]. Before 1994 during the [[Apartheid]] era, only Afrikaans and English had official status. ([[Languages of South Africa]]) *{{SDN}} – Arabic and English are the [[official language]]s. Many African languages are spoken in both North and South Sudan. ([[Languages of Sudan]]) *{{SWZ}} – English and siSwati are the [[official language]]s. Zulu is widely spoken in the southern region of the country. ([[Languages of Swaziland]]) *{{TZA}} – English and Swahili are official. Nevertheless, only the latter is a real ''lingua franca''. [[Gujarati language|Gujarati]] is spoken by many in the [[Indians in Tanzania|Indian]] community. About 120 indigenous languages from all the four language families of Africa are spoken. ([[Languages of Tanzania]]) *{{TGO}} – French is the [[official language]]. [[Ewe language|Ewe]] and [[Kabiyé language|Kabiye]] are [[national language]]s. ([[Languages of Togo]]) *{{TUN}} – Classical Arabic is official, French is often used as a language of commerce. A small percentage speaks the [[Berber language]], with its varieties like [[Tamezret]]-Berber, Matmata-Berber, [[Sened (language)|Sened-Berber]] (may be extinct) and Djerbi-Berber. ([[Languages of Tunisia]]) *{{UGA}} – English and Swahili are official. Nonetheless, Swahili is not the most widely used vernacular language despite being the vehicular language of the populace. Indeed, [[Luganda|Ganda]] is the most spoken language. Minoritiy languages include [[Soga language|Soga]], [[Nkole language|Nkole]], [[Kiga language|Kiga]], [[Teso language|Teso]], [[Masaba language|Masaba]], [[Nyoro language|Nyoro]] ([[Languages of Uganda]]) *{{SADR}} – The [[official language]]s are [[Arabic]] and [[Spanish language|Spanish]]. ([[Languages of Western Sahara]]) *{{ZMB}} – English is the [[official language]], many African languages are spoken by the country's roughly 72 different ethnic groups, with [[Nyanja]] being the most widely spoken. ([[Languages of Zambia]]) *{{ZWE}} – English is the [[official language]], but is the native language of only 2% of the population, while [[Shona language|Shona]] and [[Sindebele language|Ndebele]] are spoken by the majority of the population. ([[Languages of Zimbabwe]])
==See also== *[[Languages of the European Union]] *[[Bureau of Ghana Languages]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.acalan.org African Academy of Languages] * [http://www.ethnologue.com/browse/countries#quicktabs-browse_the_countries_of_the_worl=1 All African languages by countries]
{{African Union}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Languages Of The African Union}} [[Category:African Union]] [[Category:Languages of Africa]] [[Category:Languages of international organizations|Africa]]

page.title: List of English words of Malay origin

revision.comment: /* K */I changed Cantonese to Hokkien, since that is the correct source of the word.
revision.text:
This is a partial list of [[loanwords]] in [[English language]], that were borrowed or derived, either directly or indirectly, from [[Malay language]]. Many of the words are decisively Malay or shared with other [[Malayan languages]] group, while others obviously entered Malay both from related [[Austronesian languages]] and unrelated languages of India and China. Some may also not directly derived from Malay into English, but through other languages, in particular, that of European powers that have exercised significant influence in the [[Maritime Southeast Asia]].<ref>{{harvnb|Bartlett|1954|p=40}}</ref>
The adoption of various Malay terms began with contact between European powers and classical [[Malay sultanate]]s in the 16th century and accelerated in the 19th century with the advent of British colonisation in the region. Many of the earliest borrowing can be found in the accounts of early voyages during the [[age of discovery]], when traders and travellers brought back products and objects of natural history from Maritime Southeast Asia which became known by their native names. Over the time, with the flowering of English literature dealing with subjects native to the region, other words used to denote things and notions of [[Malay world]] and [[Malay culture|culture]], have also made their way into English.<ref>{{harvnb|Bartlett|1954|pp=40–42}}</ref> {{compact ToC|top=yes|seealso=yes|extlinks=yes}}
==A== ; [[Agar]] (also 'agar-agar'): a gelatinous substance obtained from various kinds of red seaweed and used in biological culture media and as a thickener in foods. From Malay ''agar-agar'', first known use was in 1813.<ref>{{harvnb|Merriam-Webster|p=[http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/agar agar]}}</ref> ; [[Amok]] (also 'amuck' or '{{Not a typo|amock}}'):out of control, especially when armed and dangerous; in a frenzy of violence, or on a killing spree, 'berserk', as in 'to run amok'. Adopted into English via Portuguese ''amouco'', from Malay ''amok'' ('rushing in a frenzy'). Earliest known use was in 1665 as a noun denoting a Malay in a homicidal frenzy.<ref>{{harvnb|Merriam-Webster|p=[http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/amok amok]}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Oxford dictionaries|p=[http://www.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/english/amok amok]}}</ref> ; [[Angraecum]]: [[New Latin]] modification of Malay ''anggěrik'' [[orchid]]. First known use was in 1805.<ref>{{harvnb|Merriam-Webster|p=[http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/angrecum angrecum]}}</ref> ; [[Attap]]: From the Malay word ''atap'' (thatch). Thatch made in SE Asia from Nipa palm fronds.<ref>{{harvnb|Oxford dictionaries|p= [https://en.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/attap]}}</ref>
==B== ; [[Babirusa]] (also 'babiroussa') : from French ''babiroussa'', from Malay ''babi'' hog + ''rusa'' deer. A wild pig (''Babyrousa babyrussa'') of Southeast Asia with backward-curving tusks. First known use was in 1673.<ref>{{harvnb|Merriam-Webster|p=[http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/babirusa babirusa]}}</ref> ; [[wikt:balanda|Balanda]] (also 'ballanda' or 'ballander') : from Makasarese ''balanda'', from Malay ''belanda'' (alteration of [[Hollander]] in the sense '[[Dutch people|Dutchman]]'). First known use in English was from the mid 19th century.<ref>{{harvnb|Oxford dictionaries|p=[http://www.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/english/balander?q=balanda balander]}}</ref> ; [[Bamboo]] : from Dutch ''bamboes'', based on Malay ''mambu''. First known use was in 1586.<ref>{{harvnb|Merriam-Webster|p=[http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/bamboo bamboo]}}</ref> However, the word ''buluh'' is use instead of ''mambu'' in the dictionary of Malay malaysia. But bambu (bamboo) is used in malay Indonesia ; [[Banteng]] : from Malay ''banteng'', derived from Javanese ''banṭéng''. A Southeast Asian forest ox that resembles the domestic cow, domesticated in Bali [Bos javanicus.]' First known use was in 1817.<ref>{{harvnb|Merriam-Webster|p=[http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/banteng banteng]}}</ref> ; [[Bilimbi]] : a Southeast Asian evergreen tree (Averrhoa bilimbi) resembling the carambola. Also referring to the very acid fruit of the bilimbi that is used for preserves or pickles. From [[konkani language|Konkani]] ''bilimbī'', from Malay ''bĕlimbing''.<ref>{{harvnb|Merriam-Webster|p=[http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/bilimbi bilimbi]}}</ref> ; [[Binturong]] : from ''binturong'', 'a large species of civet, ''Arctictis binturong'', of Southeast Asia'. First known use was in the early 19th century.<ref>{{harvnb|Oxford dictionaries|p=[http://www.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/english/binturong binturong]}}</ref>
==C== ; [[Tea caddy|Caddy]] : a small storage container, typically one with divisions, for example ''a tool caddy''. Also might refers to a 'tea caddy', a small tin in which tea is kept for daily use. From earlier ''[[catty]]'', denoting a unit of weight of 1 1/3 lb (0.61 kg), from Malay ''kati''. First known use was in 1792.<ref>{{harvnb|Oxford dictionaries|p=[http://www.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/english/caddy caddy]}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Merriam-Webster|p=[http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/caddy caddy]}}</ref> ; [[Catechu]] (also [[catechu|cutch]]) : any of several dry, earthy, or resinous astringent substances obtained from tropical plants of Asia, as an extract of the heartwood of an East Indian acacia (Acacia catechu) or as [[Gambier (extract)|gambier]]. [[New Latin]] modification of Malay ''kachu''; of possible [[Dravidian languages|Dravidian]] origin; akin to Tamil and Kannada ''kācu'' and ''catechu''. First known use was in 1683.<ref>{{harvnb|Merriam-Webster|p=[http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/catechu catechu]}}</ref> ; [[Caladium]] : any of a genus of tropical American plants of the [[arum]] family widely cultivated for their showy variably colored leaves. [[New Latin]] genus name, from Malay ''kěladi'', an [[Araceae|aroid plant]]. First known use was in 1881.<ref>{{harvnb|Oxford dictionaries|p=[http://www.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/english/caladium caladium]}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Merriam-Webster|p=[http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/caladium caladium]}}</ref> ; [[Camphor]] : a tough gummy volatile aromatic crystalline compound C<sub>10</sub>H<sub>16</sub>O obtained especially from the wood and bark of the camphor tree and used as a liniment and mild topical analgesic in medicine, as a plasticizer, and as an insect repellent; also : any of several similar compounds (as some terpene alcohols and ketones). Derived from [[Middle English]] ''caumfre'', from Anglo-French, from Medieval Latin ''camphora'', from Arabic ''kāfūr'', possibly from Malay ''kapur''. First known use was in the 14th century.<ref>{{harvnb|Merriam-Webster|p=[http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/camphor camphor]}}</ref> ; [[Cassowary]] : any of a genus (Casuarius) of large ratite birds chiefly of New Guinea and northern Australia that have a horny casque on the head and are closely related to the [[emu]]. Derived from Malay ''kĕsuari'', from an Austronesian language of the Moluccas. First known use was in 1611.<ref>{{harvnb|Merriam-Webster|p=[http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/cassowary cassowary]}}</ref> ; [[Carabao]] : the Water buffalo. Derived from [Spanish, from Visayan karabáw, from Malay kerbau.].<ref>{{harvnb|The Free Dictionary|p=[https://www.thefreedictionary.com/carabao]}}</ref> ; [[Casuarina]] : any of a genus (Casuarina of the family Casuarinaceae) of dicotyledonous chiefly Australian trees which have whorls of scalelike leaves and jointed stems resembling horsetails and some of which yield a heavy hard wood. [[New Latin]] genus name, from Malay ''pohon kĕsuari'', literally, 'cassowary tree'; from the resemblance of its twigs to [[cassowary]] feathers. First known use was in 1777.<ref>{{harvnb|Merriam-Webster|p=[http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/casuarina casuarina]}}</ref> ; [[Catty]] : any of various units of weight of China and Southeast Asia varying around 11⁄3 pounds (about 600 grams); also : a standard Chinese unit equal to 1.1023 pounds (500 grams). Adopted from Malay ''kati'', first known use was in 1598.<ref>{{harvnb|Merriam-Webster|p=[http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/catty catty]}}</ref> ; [[Cempedak]] (also Chempedak) : from ''Cempedak'', a species of tree and its fruit in the family Moraceae. ; [[Cockatoo]] : any of various large noisy chiefly Australasian crested parrots (family Cacatuidae and especially genus Cacatua). From Dutch ''kaketoe'', from Malay ''kakaktua''. First Known use was in 1634.<ref>{{harvnb|Merriam-Webster|p=[http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/cockatoo cockatoo]}}</ref> ; [[compound (fortification)|Compound]] (enclosed group of buildings) : a fenced or walled-in area containing a group of buildings and especially residences. Derived by [[folk etymology]] referring to such area in Southeast Asia, from Portuguese ''campon'' or Dutch ''kampoeng'', from Malay ''kampong'' ('enclosure, hamlet'). First known use was in 1679.<ref>{{harvnb|Yule|Burnell|1999|pp=240–243}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Waruno Mahdi|1999|pp=248–249}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Merriam-Webster|p=[http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/compound compound]}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Oxford dictionaries|p=[http://www.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/english/compound compound]}}</ref> ; [[Head louse|Cootie]] : [[head louse]], a type of small insect that lives in people's hair. Modification of Malay ''kutu'' of the same meaning. First known use was in 1917, popularised by British soldiers during the First World War.<ref>{{harvnb|Merriam-Webster|p=[http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/cootie cootie]}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Oxford dictionaries|p=[http://www.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/english/cootie cootie]}}</ref>
==D== ; [[Dammar]] : any of various hard resins from trees in the families ''[[Araucariaceae]]'' (genus [[Agathis]]), ''[[Dipterocarpaceae]]'' (genera Hopea, Shorea, and Vatica), and ''[[Burseraceae]]'' (genus [[Canarium]]). Derived from Malay ''damar'' ('resin'), first known use was in 1698.<ref>{{harvnb|Merriam-Webster|p=[http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/damar damar]}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Oxford dictionaries|p=[http://www.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/english/dammar dammar]}}</ref> ; [[Dugong]] : new Latin genus name of a sirenian mammal (Dugong dugon of the family ''Dugongidae'') of a monotypic genus that has a bilobed tail and in the male upper incisors altered into short tusks and that inhabits warm coastal waters chiefly of southern Asia, Australia, and northeastern Africa. Probably derived from [[Cebuano language|Cebuano]] ''dugung'', itself adopted from Malay ''duyong'' ('[[mermaid]]' or 'lady of the sea'). First known use was in 1800.<ref>{{harvnb|Merriam-Webster|p=[http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/damar damar]}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Oxford dictionaries|p=[http://www.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/english/dammar dammar]}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Winger|2000|}}</ref> ; [[Durian]] : a spiny oval tropical fruit containing a creamy pulp, famous for its fetid smell but highly valued for its flavour. Derived from Malay ''duri'' ('thorn') with noun-building suffix ''-an'', thus ''durian'' means 'thorny'. First known use was in 1588.<ref>{{harvnb|Merriam-Webster|p=[http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/durian durian]}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Oxford dictionaries|p=[http://www.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/english/durian durian]}}</ref>
==G== ; [[Uncaria gambir|Gambier]] : a yellowish [[catechu]] that is obtained from a tropical Southeast Asian woody vine (''[[Uncaria gambir]]'') of the madder family and is used for chewing with the betel nut and for tanning and dyeing. First known use was in 1830, adopted from Malay ''gambir'', the name of the plant.<ref>{{harvnb|Merriam-Webster|p=[http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/gambier gambier]}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Oxford dictionaries|p=[http://www.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/english/gambier gambier]}}</ref> ; [[Gecko]] : any small insectivorous terrestrial lizard of the family Gekkonidae, of warm regions. Their digits have adhesive pads, which enable these animals to climb on smooth surfaces. First known use was in 1774, adopted from Malay ''geko'' or ''gekok'', imitative of its cry.<ref>{{harvnb|Merriam-Webster|p=[http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/gecko gecko]}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Oxford dictionaries|p=[http://www.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/english/gecko gecko]}}</ref> ; [[Gingham]] : a cotton fabric, usually woven of two coloured yarns in a checked or striped design. First known use was in 1615, adopted via Dutch ''gingang'', from Malay ''genggang'' (originally an adjective meaning 'striped').<ref>{{harvnb|Merriam-Webster|p=[http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/gingham gingham]}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Oxford dictionaries|p=[http://www.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/english/gingham gingham]}}</ref> ; [[Godown]] : a [[warehouse]]. First known use was in 1552, by [[folk etymology]], possibly adopted via Portuguese ''gudão'', from Malay ''gudang''.<ref>{{harvnb|Merriam-Webster|p=[http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/godown godown]}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Oxford dictionaries|p=[http://www.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/english/godown godown]}}</ref> ; [[Gong]] : a disk-shaped percussion instrument that produces a resounding tone when struck with a usually padded hammer, or a saucer-shaped bell (as in a fire alarm) that is struck by a mechanical hammer, or a wire rod wound in a flat spiral for sounding the time or chime or alarm (as in a clock). First known use was in 1590, from Malay ''gong'' or ''gung'' of imitative origin.<ref>{{harvnb|Merriam-Webster|p=[http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/gong gong]}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Oxford dictionaries|p=[http://www.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/english/gong gong]}}</ref> ; [[Gutta-percha]] : a whitish rubber substance derived from the coagulated milky latex of any of these trees: used in electrical insulation and dentistry, or any of several tropical trees of the sapotaceous genera Palaquium and Payena, especially Palaquium gutta. First known use was in 1845, from Malay ''getah perca'', from ''getah'' ('gum') + ''perca'' ('strips of cloth' which it resembles), altered by association with obsolete ''gutta'' ('gum'), from Latin ''gutta'' ('a drop').<ref>{{harvnb|Merriam-Webster|p=[http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/gutta-percha gutta-percha]}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Oxford dictionaries|p=[http://www.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/english/gutta-percha gutta-percha]}}</ref>
==I== ; [[Ikat]] : a method of creating patterns in fabric by tie-dyeing the yarn before weaving, also referring to a fabric in which the yarns have been tie-dyed before weaving. First known use was in 1927, adopted from Malay ''ikat'' (literally to tie, bind, fasten).<ref>{{harvnb|Merriam-Webster|p=[http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/ikat ikat]}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Oxford dictionaries|p=[http://www.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/english/ikat ikat]}}</ref>
==J== ; [[Junk (ship)|Junk]] (type of boat) : a flat-bottomed sailing vessel of a kind typical of China and the Southeast Asia, with a prominent stem and [[lug sail]]s. First known use was in the mid 16th century: adopted via obsolete French ''juncque'' or Portuguese ''junco'', from Malay ''jong'', reinforced by Dutch ''jonk''.<ref>{{harvnb|Oxford dictionaries|p=[http://www.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/english/jong jong]}}</ref> ; [[Jelutong]] (type of timber), from Malay ''jelutong'' : A Malaysian tree with pale lightweight timber and produces a latex from which chewing gum is made.<ref>{{harvnb|Oxford dictionaries|p=[https://en.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/jelutong]}}</ref>
==K== ; [[Kampong (village)|Kampong]] : a hamlet or village in a Malay-speaking country. First known use in English was in 1844.<ref>{{harvnb|Merriam-Webster|p=[http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/kampong kampong]}}</ref> ; [[Lesser mouse-deer|Kanchil]] : any of several small chevrotains, also known as mousedeer, of Southeast Asia formerly regarded as constituting several species but now usually held to be varieties of one (Tragulus kanchil).<ref>{{harvnb|Merriam-Webster|p=[http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/kanchil kanchil]}}</ref> ; [[Ceiba pentandra|Kapok]] : a silky fibre obtained from the hairs covering the seeds of a tropical bombacaceous tree, ''[[Ceiba pentandra]]'' (kapok tree or silk-cotton tree): used for stuffing pillows, cushions, and for sound insulation. Also called, silk cotton. First known use was in 1750, adopted from Malay ''kapuk''.<ref>{{harvnb|Merriam-Webster|p=[http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/kapok kapok]}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Oxford dictionaries|p=[http://www.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/english/kapok kapok]}}</ref> ; [[Kapur (wood)|Kapur]] : a large tropical Old World tree which yields light brown timber, edible fruit, and [[camphor]]. Genus Dryobalanops, family Dipterocarpaceae. Derived from Malay ''kapur''. ; [[Ketchup]] : any of various piquant sauces containing vinegar and tomatoes, used as a relish. First known use was in 1690, derived via Malay ''kĕchap'' fish sauce, from [[Hokkien]] ''kōetsiap'' brine of pickled fish, from ''kōe'' ('seafood') + ''tsiap'' ('sauce').<ref>{{harvnb|Merriam-Webster|p=[http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/ketchup ketchup]}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Oxford dictionaries|p=[http://www.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/english/ketchup ketchup]}}</ref> ; [[Kris]] (also archaic 'creese') : an Indonesian ([[Javanese people|Javanese]]) or Malay dagger with a ridged serpentine blade. First known use was in 1580, derived from Malay ''kĕris'',<ref>{{harvnb|Merriam-Webster|p=[http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/kris kris]}}</ref> from noun-building [[prefix]] ''kĕ-'' + verb ''hiris'' ('to slice').<ref>{{harvnb|Dewan Bahasa dan Pustaka|1996|p=558}}</ref>
==L== ; [[Launch (boat)|Launch]] : a large boat that operates from a ship or a motorboat that is open or that has the forepart of the hull covered. Historically referred to the largest boat carried on a [[man-of-war]]. First known use was in 1697, possibly derived from Spanish or Portuguese ''lancha'' ('barge'), from Malay ''lancharan'' boat, from the root word ''lanchar'' ('velocity without effort' or 'action of gliding smooth primarily of boats and turtles') + noun-building suffix ''-an''.<ref>{{harvnb|Dalgado|Soares|1988|p=189}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Editors of Webster's New Dictionaries|2004|p=637}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Oxford dictionaries|p=[http://www.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/english/launch launch]}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Merriam-Webster|p=[http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/launch launch]}}</ref> ; [[Langsat]] : from Malay ''langsat'', a species of fruit-bearing tree belonging to the family Meliaceae [Lansium domesticum].<ref>{{harvnb|Merriam-Webster|p=[http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/langsat langsat]}}</ref> ; [[Latah]] : from Malay ''latah'', a condition in which abnormal behaviors result from a person experiencing a sudden shock.<ref> [[Latah]]}}</ref> ; [[Lories and lorikeets|Lory]] : any of various small brightly coloured parrots of Australasia, having a brush-tipped tongue with which to feed on nectar and pollen. First known use was in 1682, via Dutch from Malay '' lūrī'', a variant of ''nūrī.<ref>{{harvnb|Merriam-Webster|p=[http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/lory lory]}}</ref>
==M== ; [[Mandarin (bureaucrat)|Mandarin]] : a high public official of imperial China. First known use was in 1589, derived from Portuguese ''mandarim'', from Malay ''mĕntĕri'' ('minister'), itself originated from Sanskrit ''mantrin'' ('counselor'), a derivation from ''mantra'' ('counsel').<ref>{{harvnb|Merriam-Webster|p=[http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/mandarin mandarin]}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Oxford dictionaries|p=[http://www.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/english/mandarin mandarin]}}</ref> ; [[Mangosteen]] : a Southeast Asian tree, Garcinia mangostana, with thick leathery leaves and edible fruit of family Clusiaceae. Also referring to the fruit of this tree, having a sweet juicy pulp and a hard skin. First known use was in 1598, derived from Malay ''mangisutan'', a dialect variant of ''manggis''.<ref>{{harvnb|Merriam-Webster|p=[http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/mangosteen mangosteen]}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Oxford dictionaries|p=[http://www.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/english/mangosteen mangosteen]}}</ref> ; [[Shorea|Meranti]] : white, red, or yellow hardwood from a Southeast Asian tree (genus Shorea). First known use was in the late 18th century, derived from Malay ''mĕranti''.<ref>{{harvnb|Oxford dictionaries|p=[http://www.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/english/meranti meranti]}}</ref> ; [[Merbau]] : the hardwood of a Southeast Asian tree (genus Intsia). First known use was in the late 18th century, from Malay ''mĕrbau''.<ref>{{harvnb|Oxford dictionaries|p=[http://www.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/english/merbau merbau]}}</ref>
==N== ; [[Napu]] : any of several Indo-Malayan chevrotains resembling but larger than the [[kanchil]]s and probably all varieties of a single species (Tragulus javanicus). Derived from Malay ''napoh''.<ref>{{harvnb|Merriam-Webster|p=[http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/napu napu]}}</ref> ; [[Nypa fruticans|Nipa]] : a palm tree with creeping roots, characteristic of mangrove swamps in India and the Pacific islands. First known use was in 1779, denoting an alcoholic drink made from the sap of the tree, via Spanish or Portuguese, from Malay ''nīpah''.<ref>{{harvnb|Oxford dictionaries|p=[http://www.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/english/nipa nipa]}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Merriam-Webster|p=[http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/nipa nipa]}}</ref>
==O== ; [[Orangutan]] : a large anthropoid ape, Pongo pygmaeus, of the forests of Sumatra and Borneo, with shaggy reddish-brown hair and strong arms. First known use was in 1691, [[Bazaar Malay]] (Malay-based pidgin), from Malay ''ōrang'' ('man') + ''hūtan'' ('forest').<ref>{{harvnb|Merriam-Webster|p=[http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/orangutan orangutan]}}</ref>
==P== ; [[Paddy field|Paddy]] : 'rice paddy', [[rice]] as a growing crop or when harvested but not yet milled. Also called 'paddy field', referring to the [[rice|rice plant]] ''Oryza sativa''. Derived from Malay ''pādī'', first known use was in 1623.<ref>{{harvnb|Merriam-Webster|p=[http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/paddy paddy]}}</ref> ; [[Pandanus]] : a tropical tree or shrub with a twisted stem, long spiny leaves, and fibrous edible fruit.[Genus Pandanus.]. New Latin genus name, from Malay ''pandan'' screw pine, first known use was in 1830.<ref>{{harvnb|Merriam-Webster|p=[http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/paddy paddy]}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Oxford dictionaries|p=[http://www.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/english/pandanus pandanus]}}</ref> ; [[Pangolin]] : any mammal of the order Pholidota found in tropical Africa and Southeast Asia, having a body covered with overlapping horny scales and a long snout specialized for feeding on ants and termites. First known use was in 1774, derived from Malay ''pĕngguling'' ('one that rolls/curls'), from the root word ''guling'' ('to roll over'); from its ability to roll into a ball.<ref>{{harvnb|Merriam-Webster|p=[http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/pangolin pangolin]}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Oxford dictionaries|p=[http://www.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/english/pangolin pangolin]}}</ref> ; [[Pantoum]] : a verse form consisting of a series of quatrains in which the second and fourth lines of each verse are repeated as the first and third lines of the next. Derived via French, from Malay ''[[pantun]]''. First known use was in the late 18th century.<ref>{{harvnb|Merriam-Webster|p=[http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/pantun pantun]}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Oxford dictionaries|p=[http://www.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/english/pantun pantun]}}</ref> ; [[Parang (knife)|Parang]] : a short sword, cleaver, or [[machete]] common in Malaysia and Indonesia. First known use was in 1839, derived from Malay ''parang''.<ref>{{harvnb|Merriam-Webster|p=[http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/parang parang]}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Oxford dictionaries|p=[http://www.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/english/parang parang]}}</ref> ; [[Picul]] : a unit of weight used in China and South-East Asia equal to 100 catties (approx. 133 lb, 60.4 kg). Earliest use was from the late 16th century, in the work of a translator, Robert Parke (fl. 1588–1589). Derived from Malay ''pīkul'', a load as heavy as an ordinary man can lift, 100-catty weight.<ref>{{harvnb|Oxford dictionaries|p=[http://www.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/english/picul picul]}}</ref> ; [[Proa]] (also 'prahu' or 'prau'): any of several kinds of canoe-like boats used in the Southeast Asia, especially one equipped with a large triangular sail and an outrigger. Earliest known use was in 1582, from Malay ''pĕrahu''.<ref>{{harvnb|Merriam-Webster|p=[http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/prau prau]}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Oxford dictionaries|p=[http://www.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/english/proa proa]}}</ref> ; [[Pulasan]] : a Southeast Asian tropical fruit that resembles the closely related [[rambutan]] but is sweeter and less juicy. Derived from Malay ''pulasan'',<ref>{{harvnb|Merriam-Webster|p=[http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/pulasan pulasan]}}</ref> from the root word ''pulas'' ('to twist' referring to the act of twisting the fruit with both hands to open it) + noun-building suffix ''-an''.
==R== ; [[Rambutan]] : a bright red spiny Southeast Asian fruit closely related to the lychee; also referring to the tree (Nephelium lappaceum) of the soapberry family that bears this fruit. Earliest known use was in 1707, from Malay ''rambūtan'', from the root word ''rambūt'' ('hairy', with allusion to the fruit's spines) + noun-building suffix ''-an''.<ref>{{harvnb|Merriam-Webster|p=[http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/rambutan rambutan]}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Oxford dictionaries|p=[http://www.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/english/rambutan rambutan]}}</ref> ; [[Ramie]] : a woody urticaceous shrub of Asia, Boehmeria nivea, having broad leaves and a stem that yields a flaxlike fibre. Also referring to the fibre from this plant, used in making fabrics, cord. First known use was in 1832, from Malay ''rami''.<ref>{{harvnb|Merriam-Webster|p=[http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/ramie ramie]}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Oxford dictionaries|p=[http://www.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/english/ramie ramie]}}</ref> ; [[Rattan]] : any of the climbing palms of the genus Calamus and related genera, having tough stems used for wickerwork and canes. Also referring to the stems of such plants collectively and a stick made from one of these stems. Earliest known use was in 1660, from Malay ''rōtan'', probably derived from ''raut'' ('pare' or 'trim').<ref>{{harvnb|Merriam-Webster|p=[http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/rattan rattan]}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Oxford dictionaries|p=[http://www.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/english/rattan rattan]}}</ref> ; [[Ringgit]] : the standard monetary unit of [[Malaysia]], divided into 100 sen. Literally 'serration', referring to the serrated edges of silver [[Spanish dollar]]s which circulated widely in the area during the 16th and 17th century. First known use in English was in 1967.<ref>{{harvnb|Merriam-Webster|p=[http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/ringgit ringgit]}}</ref>
==S== ; [[Sago]] : a starchy cereal obtained from the powdered pith of a [[Metroxylon sagu|sago palm]], used for puddings and as a thickening agent. From Malay ''sāgū'', possibly via Portuguese. Earliest known use was in 1580.<ref>{{harvnb|Merriam-Webster|p=[http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/sago sago]}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Oxford dictionaries|p=[http://www.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/english/sago sago]}}</ref> ; [[Salak]] : from ''salak'', ' a species of palm tree (family Arecaceae) native to Indonesia and Malaysia [Salacca zalacca]'.<ref>{{harvnb|Merriam-Webster|p=[http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/salak salak]}}</ref> ; [[Sambal]] : a condiment made typically of peppers, pickles, grated coconut, salt fish, or fish roe and eaten especially with curry and rice. Derived from Malay ''sambal''.<ref>{{harvnb|Merriam-Webster|p=[http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/sambal sambal]}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Oxford dictionaries|p=[http://www.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/english/sambal sambal]}}</ref> ; [[Caesalpinia sappan|Sapan]] : a small leguminous tree, ''[[Caesalpinia sappan]]'', of Southeast Asia producing wood that yields a red dye. Derived via Dutch ''sapan'' in 16th century, from Malay ''sapang''.<ref>{{harvnb|Collins Dictionary|p=[http://www.collinsdictionary.com/dictionary/english/sapanwood#sapanwood_1 sapan]}}</ref> ; [[Sarong]] : a draped skirtlike garment worn by men and women in the Southeast Asia, Sri Lanka, and the Pacific islands. Earliest known use was in 1830, derived from Malay ''sarung'' (literally 'to sheath').<ref>{{harvnb|Merriam-Webster|p=[http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/sarong sarong]}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Oxford dictionaries|p=[http://www.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/english/sarong sarong]}}</ref> ; [[Satay]] (also 'sate') : from Malay ''satai'', Javanese/Indonesian "sate", an Indonesian and Malaysian dish consisting of small pieces of meat grilled on a skewer and served with spiced sauce.<ref>{{harvnb|Merriam-Webster|p=[http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/satay satay]}}</ref> ; [[Seladang]] : a wild ox with a dark brown or black coat with white lower legs, native to India and Malaysia. [Bos gaurus.] . First known use was in the early 19th century, derived from Malay ''sĕladang''.<ref>{{harvnb|Merriam-Webster|p=[http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/seladang seladang]}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Oxford dictionaries|p=[http://www.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/english/seladang seladang]}}</ref> ; [[Siamang]] : a large black gibbon native to Sumatra and Malaya [Hylobates syndactylus.] Earliest known use was in 1822, from Malay ''siamang''.<ref>{{harvnb|Merriam-Webster|p=[http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/siamang siamang]}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Oxford dictionaries|p=[http://www.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/english/siamang siamang]}}</ref> ; [[Silat Melayu|Silat]] : the Malay art of self-defence, practised as a martial art or accompanied by drums as a ceremonial display or dance.<ref>{{harvnb|Merriam-Webster|p=[http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/silat silat]}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Oxford dictionaries|p=[http://www.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/english/silat silat]}}</ref>
==T== ; [[Tael]] : a unit of weight, used in the Far East, having various values between one and two and a half ounces. Also formerly a Chinese monetary unit equivalent in value to a tael weight of standard silver. Earliest known use was in 1588, adopted via Portuguese, from Malay ''tahil'' (literally 'weight').<ref>{{harvnb|Merriam-Webster|p=[http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/tael tael]}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Oxford dictionaries|p=[http://www.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/english/tael tael]}}</ref> ; [[Thai baht|Tical]] : an archaic monetary unit of Malay origin, ''tikal''. Adopted into English possibly via Thai or Portuguese, first known use was in 1662.<ref>{{harvnb|Merriam-Webster|p=[http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/tical tical]}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Collins Dictionary|p=[http://www.collinsdictionary.com/dictionary/english/tical tical]}}</ref> ; [[Tokay gecko|Tokay]] : a small gecko, ''Gekko gecko'', of South and Sotheast Asia, having a retractile claw at the tip of each digit. Derived from Malay ''toke''' or ''tokek'', of imitative origin. First known use was in 1696.<ref>{{harvnb|Merriam-Webster|p=[http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/tokay tokay]}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Collins Dictionary|p=[http://www.collinsdictionary.com/dictionary/english/tokay tokay]}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Oxford dictionaries|p=[http://www.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/english/tokay tokay]}}</ref> ; [[Tombac]] : any of various brittle alloys containing copper and zinc and sometimes tin and arsenic: used for making cheap jewellery. A French term derived from Dutch ''tombak'', in turn from Malay ''tĕmbaga'' ('copper'), apparently from Sanskrit ''tāmraka'', from the root word ''tāmra'' ('dark coppery red'). Earliest known use in English was in 1602.<ref>{{harvnb|Merriam-Webster|p=[http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/tombac tombac]}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Collins Dictionary|p=[http://www.collinsdictionary.com/dictionary/english/tombac tombac]}}</ref> ; [[Trepanging|Trepang]] : any of several large sea cucumbers (as of the genera Actinopyga and Holothuria) that are taken mostly in the southwestern Pacific and are boiled, dried, and used especially in Asian cuisine, also called ''bêche-de-mer''. From Malay ''těripang'', first known use was in 1783.<ref>{{harvnb|Merriam-Webster|p=[http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/trepang trepang]}}</ref>
== See also == * [[Lists of English words of international origin]] * [[Wiktionary:Category:Malay derivations|The category of words with Malay derivations]] at [[Wiktionary]], Wikipedia's sister project

{{Infobox language |name=Medumba |altname=Bagangte |nativename=''Mə̀dʉ̂mbɑ̀'' |region=[[Cameroon]] |ethnicity=[[Bamileke people|Bamileke]] |speakers=210,000 |date=1991 |ref=e18 |familycolor=Niger-Congo |fam2=[[Atlantic–Congo]] |fam3=[[Benue–Congo]] |fam4=[[Southern Bantoid]] |fam5=[[Grassfields languages|Grassfields]] |fam6=[[Eastern Grassfields languages|Eastern]] |fam7=[[Bamileke languages|Bamileke]] |dia1=Batongtou |iso3=byv |glotto=medu1238 |glottorefname=Medumba }}'''Medumba''' (''Mə̀dʉ̂mbɑ̀'' {{IPA|mə̀ɟʝʉ̂ᵐbɑ̀}}) is a [[Grassfields language]] of [[Cameroon]]. The people who speak it originate from the [[Ndé|Nde]] division of the [[West Region (Cameroon)|West Region]] of the country, with their main settlements in [[Bangangté]], Bakong, Bangoulap, Bahouoc, Bagnoun and Tonga. It is a major [[Bamileke language]], and is located in an area where [[sacred king]]ship played a pivotal role in government, justice, and diplomacy.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Warnier|first=Jean-Pierre|date=2015|title=Review of "Nation of Outlaws, State of Violence: Nationalism, Grassfields Tradition, and State Building in Cameroon" by Meredith Terretta|url=https://muse.jhu.edu/article/592097/pdf|journal=African Studies Review|volume=58|pages=255–257|via=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Feldman-Savelsberg|first=Pamela|date=1995|title=Cooking inside: Kinship and Gender in Bangangté Idioms of Marriage and Procreation|jstor=645968|journal=American Ethnologist|series=3|volume=22|pages=483–501|access-date=|via=}}</ref> The modern history of the Bamileke area, which was a German colony placed under French trusteeship by the League of Nations in 1919, is closely associated with the nationalist movement of the [[Union des populations du Cameroun|Union des Populations du Cameroun]] (UPC), which developed primarily in the coastal hinterland (Bassa) and the western highlands (Bamileke). From 1956 to the late 1960s, this area of Cameroon experienced a period of unrest;<ref>{{Cite book |title=Nation of Outlaws, State of Violence: Nationalism, Grassfields Tradition, and State Building in Cameroon |last=Terretta |first=Meredith |publisher=Ohio University Press |year=2014 |isbn=978-0821420690 |location=Athens|pages=xiv, 36}}</ref> this episode continues to shape Bamileke political culture, and has an impact on language identity<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Bandia|first=Paul F|date=1993|title=Translation as Culture Transfer: Evidence from African Creative Writing|url=|journal=TTR: Traduction, mixité, politique|volume=6|issue=2|pages=55–78|doi=10.7202/037151ar|via=}}</ref> and the [[linguistic landscape]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Ndjio|first=Basile|date=2009|title=Migration, Architecture, and the Transformation of the Landscape in the Bamileke Grassfields of West Cameroon|url=|journal=African Diaspora|volume=2|pages=73–100|doi=10.1163/187254609X430777|via=}}</ref>
The Medumba-speaking area is famous for a bi-annual cultural festival — ''FESTAC: [[:fr:Festival des arts et de la culture medumba|Festival des arts et de la culture]]'' [[:fr:Festival des arts et de la culture medumba|''Medumba'']] (Medumba Arts and Crafts Festival) — that promotes the Medumba language, as well as dance, artwork and food styles of the 14 different villages of the locality.<ref>{{Cite book|url=http://www.theseus.fi/bitstream/handle/10024/80002/nana%20dorothy%20thesis.pdf?sequence=1&isAllowed=y|title=The impact of event tourism on host communities (Case, Northwest Region of Cameroon)|last=Chubo|first=Nana Dorothy|work=Master's Thesis, Centria University of Applied Sciences, Unit for Kokkola-Piertarsaari|publisher=|year=2014|isbn=|location=|pages=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=2WvdPfMrrY0C&lpg=PA18&ots=CmGDyLdhnr&dq=Medumba%20Arts%20and%20Crafts%20Festival&pg=PR2#v=onepage&q=Medumba%20Arts%20and%20Crafts%20Festival&f=false|title=Cameroon (Third Edition)|last=West|first=Ben|publisher=Bradt Travel Guides Limited|year=2011|isbn=978 1 84162 353 5|location=IDC House, The Vale, Chalfont St Peter, Bucks, Englad|pages=18}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201607260437.html|title=Cameroon: Bangangté - Medumba Festival Ends On Thrilling Note|last=Fosong|first=David|date=25 July 2016|work=AllAfrica.com|access-date=14 March 2018|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> The festival, which takes place over a 2-week period in early July, is hosted in Bangangte.
== Language resources ==
=== Scholarship on the Bamileke cluster === Medumba is part of the Eastern Group of the [[Bamileke languages|Bamileke]] Cluster, which also include [[Fe'fe' language|Fe'fe']], [[Ghomala' language|Ghomálá']], [[Kwa’ language|Kwa']], and [[Nda’nda’ language|Nda'nda']]. The Bamileke cluster — along with Ngemba, Nkambe and Nun — is part of the [[Eastern Grassfields languages|Eastern Grassfields]] subgroup which, together with the [[Ring languages]] and the [[Southwest Grassfields languages|Southwest Grassfields]] languages, constitute the [[Grassfields languages|Grassfield Bantu]] grouping. {{Grassfields Bantu languages}} Medumba figures prominently in linguistic research on the Bamileke cluster, partly because of the high quality of the work done by Jan Voorhoeve in the 1960s and 1970s, including work on (in chronological order): * morpheme structure constraints (Voorhoeve 1965<ref name=":8" />) * personal pronouns (Voorhoeve 1967<ref name=":9" />) * noun classes (Voorhoeve 1967<ref name=":4" /> and 1969<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Voorhoeve|first=Jan|date=1969|editor-last=Voorhoeve|editor-first=Jan|editor2-last=de Wolf|editor2-first=Paul|title=Benue-Congo noun class systems: Bangangte|trans-title=|url=|journal=|location=West African Linguistic Society (Africka - Studiecentrum) Leiden|volume=|pages=17–19|via=}}</ref>) * tone of nouns (Voorhoeve 1971<ref name=":0" />) * traditional Bamileke narratives (Voorhoeve 1976<ref>{{Cite book|title=Contes Bamileke|last=Voorhoeve|first=Jan|publisher=Musée Royal de L'Afrique Centrale|year=1976|isbn=|series=Annales - Série In.8 - Sciences Humaine no. 89|location=Tervuren, Belgium|pages=}}</ref>) * general linguistic description of the Bangangte dialect (Voorhoeve 1977<ref>{{Cite book|title=Bamileke (Bangangte dialect)|last=Voorhoeve|first=Jan|work=West African Language Data Sheets (Volume 1)|publisher=West African Linguistic Society|year=1977|isbn=|editor-last=Kropp Dakubu|editor-first=M. E.|location=|pages=57–66}}</ref>)
This work was pursued by L. Hyman in the 1980s, on the closely related language Fe'fe' (add refs). It was re-invigorated in the early 2010s by research groups at Boston University (lead by C. O'Connor) and at the University of British Columbia (lead by R.-M. Déchaine). Some of these publications include: * [add refs] Also notable are the scholarly contributions of Medumba speaker-linguists, including (in chronological order): * Keupdjio 2011, MA thesis (University of Yaounde) on content questions<ref>{{Cite book|title=Les mouvements Qu et l'architecture propositionnelle en Medumba|last=Keupdjio|first=Hermann|publisher=The University of Yaounde 1 Master's Thesis|year=2011|isbn=|location=|pages=}}</ref> * Kouankem 2011, PhD dissertation (University of Yaounde) on nominal syntax<ref name=":6">{{Cite book|title=The syntax of the Medumba determiner phrase|last=Constantine|first=Kouankem|publisher=University of Yaounde 1 PhD Dissertation, 350 pp|year=2011|isbn=|location=|pages=}}</ref> * Kouankem 2013 on concord<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Kouankem|first=Constantine|date=2013|title=Determiner phrase structure and concord in Medumba|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.2989/02572117.2013.793941|journal=South African Journal of African Languages|volume=33:1|pages=59–64|via=}}</ref> Recent work on Medumba is part of a more general push towards documenting the languages of Africa, in the face of rising levels of language endangerment.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/973733564|title=Africa's endangered languages : documentary and theoretical approaches|others=Kandybowicz, Jason,, Torrence, Harold,|isbn=9780190256340|location=New York, NY|oclc=973733564}}</ref> Cameroon — along with Nigeria, Sudan, and Ethiopia — is reported to have one of the highest language mortality rates in Africa.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Okal|first=Bernad Odoyo|date=2014|title=Benefits of Multilingualism in Education |journal=Universal Journal of Educational Research|volume=2|issue=3 |page=228 |doi=10.13189/ujer.2014.020304}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=|title=How Kenya Stands to Lose More than 10 Tribes|last=Opala|first=K.|date=6 March 2002|work=Daily Nation |publisher=Nation Media Group|location=Nairobi}}</ref>
=== Literacy and orthography === Efforts to develop a Medumba orthography date back to the beginning of the 20th century,<ref>{{Cite book|title=Swαndα Mə́dʉmbà: Lexique Français-Mə́dʉmbà (4500 mots) et 260 expression françaises-mə́dʉmbà|last=Tchana|first=Thomas|publisher=Comite de langue bamileke medujba, Production du CEPOM|year=2009|isbn=|location=Bangangte, Cameroon|pages=}}</ref> and are associated with the following milestones: * '''1926''': Protestant missionaries develop an orthography for use in primary schools to facilitate the penetration of the Christian Bible in the region. * '''1957''': The French administration prohibits the use of local languages in the territories of the Union Française. * '''1973''', 20 December: CEPOM (''Comité de Langue pour l'Etude et la Production des Œuvres Bamiléké-Medumba'') is created; its mission is to promote research on Medumba and develop literacy materials. *
Currently, educational materials, literature and dictionaries for the language are produced by CEPOM, based in Bangangte. The combined output of missionary and CEPOM work has produced more that 80 publications on Medumba language and culture; these are published in French, English, and Medumba. Over time, publications in Medumba have used six different orthographies:<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Bird|first=Stephen|date=2001|title=Orthography and identity in Cameroon|url=|journal=Written Language & Literacy|volume=4|issue=2|pages=131–162|doi=10.1075/wll.4.2.02bir|via=}}</ref> * '''1926''': published in a collection of 12 songs * '''1945''': published in a book on religious history (''Nu Yawe Nsi'') and a syllabary * '''1967''': publication of the New Testament (''Kàn nswe'') and ''Tshô Pangante'' * '''1973''': publication of ''Cam Medumba'' and ''zi'te nkite''. * '''1979''': publication of ''Mbwog NkUd MedUmbA'' and ''Tons, Textes''… * '''1985''', 2 February: adoption of the current orthography at the 4th CEPOM Council The current alphabet is given in Table 1. {| class="wikitable mw-collapsible mw-collapsed" ! colspan="34" |'''Table 1. Alphabet''' |- |Uppercase |[[:fr:A (lettre)|A]] |[[:fr:Ɑ|Ɑ]] |[[:fr:B (lettre)|B]] |[[:fr:C (lettre)|C]] |[[:fr:D (lettre)|D]] |[[:fr:Ə|Ə]] |[[:fr:E (lettre)|E]] |[[:fr:Ɛ|Ɛ]] |[[:fr:F (lettre)|F]] |[[:fr:G (lettre)|G]] |[[:fr:Gh (digramme)|Gh]] |[[:fr:H (lettre)|H]] |[[:fr:I (lettre)|I]] |[[:fr:J (lettre)|J]] |[[:fr:K (lettre)|K]] |[[:fr:L (lettre)|L]] |[[:fr:M (lettre)|M]] |[[:fr:N (lettre)|N]] |[[:fr:Ŋ|Ŋ]] |[[:fr:O (lettre)|O]] |[[:fr:Ɔ|Ɔ]] |[[:fr:S (lettre)|S]] |[[:fr:Sh (digramme)|Sh]] |[[:fr:T (lettre)|T]] |[[:fr:Ts (digramme)|Ts]] |[[:fr:U (lettre)|U]] |[[:fr:Ʉ|Ʉ]] |[[:fr:V (lettre)|V]] |[[:fr:W (lettre)|W]] |[[:fr:Ny (digramme)|Ny]] |[[:fr:Y (lettre)|Y]] |[[:fr:Z (lettre)|Z]] |[[:fr:Apostrophe (typographie)|ʼ]] |- |Lowercase |a |ɑ |b |c |d |ə |e |ɛ |f |g |gh |h |i |j |k |l |m |n |ŋ |o |ɔ |s |sh |t |ts |u |ʉ |v |w |ny |y |z |ʼ |- |IPA symbol |a |ɑ |b |tʃ |d |ə |ɪ |ɛ |f |g |ɣ |x |i |ɟ |k |l |m |n |ŋ |o |ɔ |s |ʃ |t |ʦ |u, ʊ |ʉ |v |w |ɲ |j |z |ʔ |} In addition to simplex consonants, Medumba has numerous complex consonants, and these are represented as [[Digraph (orthography)|digraphs]] or [[Trigraph (orthography)|trigraphs]]; see Table 2. Nasals, stops, and fricatives can be labliazed; in the orthography this is represented as a CW digraph. [[Stop consonant|Stops]] and [[Fricative consonant|fricatives]] can be [[Prenasalized consonant|pre-nasalized]]; in the orthography this is represented as an NC digraph or an NCW trigraph. {| class="wikitable mw-collapsible mw-collapsed" ! colspan="26" |Table 2. Orthographic conventions for complex consonants |- ! ! colspan="9" |Labialized consonants ! colspan="16" |Pre-nasalized consonants |- ! rowspan="2" | ! colspan="2" rowspan="2" |nasals ! colspan="5" |stops ! colspan="2" rowspan="2" |fricatives ! colspan="12" |stops ! colspan="4" rowspan="2" |fricatives |- ! colspan="3" |voiced ! colspan="2" |voiceless ! colspan="7" |voiced ! colspan="5" |voiceless |- |Uppercase |[[:fr:N (lettre)|N]]<nowiki/>w |[[:fr:Ŋ|Ŋ]]<nowiki/>w |[[:fr:B (lettre)|B]]<nowiki/>w |[[:fr:J (lettre)|J]]<nowiki/>w |[[:fr:G (lettre)|Gw]] |[[:fr:C (lettre)|C]]<nowiki/>w |[[:fr:K (lettre)|K]]<nowiki/>w |[[:fr:F (lettre)|F]]<nowiki/>w |[[:fr:S (lettre)|S]]<nowiki/>w |Mb |Mbw |Nd |Nj |Nj |[[:fr:Ŋ|Ŋ]]<nowiki/>g |[[:fr:Ŋ|Ŋ]]<nowiki/>gw |Nt |Nc |Ncw |[[:fr:Ŋ|Ŋ]]<nowiki/>kw |[[:fr:Ŋ|Ŋ]]<nowiki/>kw |Mf |Mfw |Ns |Nsw |- |Lowercase |nw |ŋw |bw |jw |gw |cw |kw |fw |sw |mb |mbw |nd |nj |njw |ŋg |ŋgw |nt |nc |ncw |ŋk |ŋkw |mf |mfw |ns |nsw |- |IPA symbol |ɲʷ |ŋʷ |bʰ |ɟʷ, ʒʷ |gʷ |tʃʷ |kʷ |fʷ |sʷ |ᵐb |ᵐbʰ |ⁿd |ᶮɟ,ⁿʒ |ᶮɟʷ,ⁿʒʷ |ᵑg |ᵑgᵂ |ⁿt |ᶮc |ᶮcᵂ |ᵑk |ᵑkᵂ |ᵐf |ᵐfᵂ |ⁿs |ⁿsᵂ |} Orthographic conventions for tone-marking are as follows: * High-tone is not marked * Low-tone is marked as a grave accent on the vowel, e.g. '''à''' * Rising Low-High is marked as a hatcheck on a single vowel, e.g. '''ɛˇ''' * Falling High-Low is marked as circumflex on a single vowel, e.g. '''ʉ̂''' Recent developments in digital literacy have had an impact on Medumba. For example, a seven-language electronic calendar — in French, English, and the five national languages (Medumba, Ghomala, Yemba, Meta, Kom) — sends information on time and date to an LCD screen via a VGA controller. The calendar has been developed as a way of mitigating the impact of language competition, and with the specific goal of raising the profile and prestige of the national languages in a context of language endangerment.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Tchahou Tchendjeu|first=A. E.|last2=Tchitnga|first2=R.|last3=Fotsin|first3=H. B.|date=July 2016|title=FPGA based seven-language electronic calendar for the revival of the cameroon culture|url=http://www.iut-douala.cm/sites/default/files/articles%20colloque/Tchahou%20Tchendjeu%20et%20al.Full.STD2016.pdf|journal=Sciences, Technologies et Développement (Edition spéciale)|volume=|pages=197–202|via=}}</ref>
=== Medumba radio station === Radio FM 100 Medumba was established in 2000 by ''Medumba Kum Ntsi''.<ref>{{Cite journal|date=2016-08-28|title=Festival des arts et de la culture medumba|url=https://fr.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Festival_des_arts_et_de_la_culture_medumba&oldid=129065851|journal=Wikipédia|language=fr}}</ref>
== Segments == Initial research on the Medumba segment inventory was conducted by Voorhoeve in the early 1960s, and published in Voorhoeve (1965).<ref name=":8" /> He identified15 [[vowel]]s and 40 [[consonant]]s. Not described by Voorhoeve (1965) are the plain and pre-nasalized bilabial trills /B/, /ᵐB/, which occur most often before central vowels /ʉ, ə/, which brings the total number of consonants to 42.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Olson|first=Kenneth S.|last2=Meynadier|first2=Yohann|date=2015|title=On Medumba Bilabial Trills and Vowels|url=http://www.internationalphoneticassociation.org/icphs-proceedings/ICPhS2015/Papers/ICPHS0522.pdf|journal=Proceedings of the International Phonetic Association|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref> The following two subsections survey the vowel and consonant inventory.
=== Vowels: 15 vowels === Medumba has a 10 simplex vowels, and 5 complex vowels ([[diphthong]]s).
==== Simple vowels ==== Table 3 gives the inventory of simple vowels, which include 5 [[Close vowel|closed]] (high) vowels /i, ʉ, u, ɪ, ʊ/ and 5 non-closed (non-high) /e, ə, o, a, ɑ/. See (1-10) for examples.

=== Consonants: 42 consonants === The canonical morpheme in Medumba is a single [[syllable]], either an [[Open syllable|open CV syllable]] or a [[Syllable|closed CVC syllable]] (Voorhoeve 1965:319).<ref name=":8">{{Cite journal|last=Voorhoeve|first=Jan|last2=|date=|year=1965|title=The Structure of the Morpheme in Bamileke (Bangangté dialect)|url=|journal=Lingua|volume=13|pages=319–334|via=}}</ref> This morpheme structure constraint has consequences for the consonant inventory. Indeed, a notable property of Medumba is that the number of [[Contrastive distribution|contrastive]] consonants differs according to whether one considers consonants in [[Syllable|onset]] position (i.e., consonants that begin a '''C'''V or '''C'''VC syllable) or consonants in coda position (i.e. consonants that end a CV'''C''' syllable). Below, the consonant inventory is introduced, and the distributional differences between coda (C2) and onset (C1) consonants are described.
Medumba has 42 consonants, of which 18 are simplex consonants and 24 are complex consonants.
==== Simplex consonants ==== Table 5 gives the inventory of the 18 simplex consonants (Voorhoeve 1965); they are displayed according to [[place of articulation]] ([[Labial consonant|labial]], [[Alveolar consonant|alveolar]], [[Palatal consonant|palatal]], [[Velar consonant|velar]], [[Glottal stop|glottal]]), and [[manner of articulation]] ([[Nasal consonant|nasal stop]], [[Stop consonant|oral stop]], [[Fricative consonant|fricative]]). There are 4 [[Nasal consonant|nasals]] [m, n], ɲ, ŋ], 4 voiced stops [b, d, j, g], 4 voiceless stops [t, c, k, ʔ]), and 2 voiced fricatives (v, z) and 3 voiceless fricatives (f, s, ʃ). Dashes (--) indicate gaps in the consonant inventory.
{| class="wikitable mw-collapsible mw-collapsed" ! colspan="9" |Table 5. Simplex consonants |- ! colspan="4" rowspan="2" | ! colspan="5" |Place of articulation |- !labial !alveolar !palatal !velar !glottal |- | rowspan="6" |'''Manner of''' '''articulation''' | rowspan="3" |'''stop''' | colspan="2" |'''nasal''' (n = 4) |m |n |ɲ |ŋ | |- | rowspan="2" |'''oral''' |'''voiced''' (n = 4) |b |d |'''ɟ''' |ɡ | |- |'''voiceless''' (n = 4) |<nowiki>--</nowiki> |'''t''' |'''c''' |'''k''' |'''''ʔ''''' |- | colspan="2" |'''trill''' |'''voiced''' (n=1) |B | | | | |- | colspan="2" rowspan="2" |'''fricative''' |'''voiced''' (n = 2) |('''v''') |('''z''') |<nowiki>--</nowiki> |<nowiki>--</nowiki> | |- |'''voiceless''' (n = 3) |'''f''' |'''s''' |('''ʃ''') |<nowiki>--</nowiki> | |- | colspan="9" |(adapted from Voorhoeve 1965:320, footnote 6; Voorhoeve uses /j/ as the symbol for a palatal stop; the [[International Phonetic Alphabet|IPA]] convention is /ɟ/.) '''Boldface''' symbols { '''ɟ''', '''t''', '''c''', '''k''', '''f''', '''s, v, z'''} occur only in onset position.
'''''Boldface italic''''' symbols '''''ʔ''''', occur only in coda position.
Symbols in parentheses, namely ('''v'''), ('''z'''), and ('''ʃ'''), are extremely rare as phonemes. |} Note the absence of the following segments: * there is a voiced bilabial stop /b/, but no counterpart voiceless bilabial stop '''*/p/''' ** but [p] occurs as an [[allophone]] of /b/ * there is a voiceless palatal fricative /'''ʃ'''/ (with limited distribution), but no counterpart voiced palatal fricative '''*/ʒ/''' ** but [ʒ] occurs as an allophone of /ɟ/ * there are velar nasal and oral stops, but no counterpart velar fricatives */'''ɣ'''/ or */'''x'''/ ** but [ɣ] occurs as a release in the /ᵑg/~[ᵑgˠ] alternation, and [x] occurs as a release in the /ᵑk/~[ᵑkˣ] alternation
==== Complex consonants ==== Table 6 gives the inventory of the 24 [[Co-articulated consonant|complex consonants]] found in Medumba (Voorhoeve 1965:326, section 3.1.9); they are displayed according to the primary place of articulation (labial, alveolar, palatal and velar) and the nature of the [[secondary articulation]] (labialized, pre-nasalized, and pre-nasalized labialized). This includes 8 [[Labialization|labialized]] consonants ('''Cᵂ'''), 10 [[Prenasalized consonant|pre-nasalized]] consonants ('''ᴺC'''), and 6 pre-nasalized labialized stops ('''ᴺCᵂ'''). Complex consonants only occur in onset position; see the next section for exemplification. {| class="wikitable mw-collapsible mw-collapsed" ! colspan="7" |Table 6. Complex consonants |- ! colspan="3" rowspan="2" | ! colspan="4" |Place of Primary Articulation |- !labial !alveolar !palatal !velar |- | rowspan="11" |'''Secondary''' '''Articulation''' | rowspan="4" |'''labialized''' '''Cᵂ''' (n = 8) |'''nasal''' |<nowiki>--</nowiki> |<nowiki>--</nowiki> |ɲᵂ |ŋᵂ |- |'''stop, voiced''' |bᵂ |<nowiki>--</nowiki> |ɟᵂ |gᵂ |- |'''stop, voiceless''' |<nowiki>--</nowiki> |<nowiki>--</nowiki> |cᵂ |kᵂ |- |'''fricative''' | -- |sᵂ |<nowiki>--</nowiki> |<nowiki>--</nowiki> |- | rowspan="4" |'''pre-nasalized''' '''ᴺC''' (n = 10) |'''trill, voiced''' |ᵐB | | | |- |'''plosive, voiced''' |ᵐb |ⁿd |ᶮɟ |ᵑg |- |'''plosive, voiceless''' |<nowiki>--</nowiki> |ⁿt |ᶮc |ᵑk |- |'''fricative''' |ᵐf |ⁿs |<nowiki>--</nowiki> |<nowiki>--</nowiki> |- | rowspan="3" |'''pre-nasalized labialized''' '''ᴺCᵂ''' (n = 6) |'''plosive, voiced''' |ᵐbᵂ |<nowiki>--</nowiki> |ᶮɟᵂ |ᵑgᵂ |- |'''plosive, voiced''' |<nowiki>--</nowiki> |<nowiki>--</nowiki> |ᶮcᵂ |ᵑkᵂ |- |'''fricative''' | -- |ⁿsᵂ |<nowiki>--</nowiki> |<nowiki>--</nowiki> |- | colspan="7" |(adapted from Voorhoeve 1965:326) |} Note the following gaps in the inventory of complex consonants: * no labialized labial nasal or voiceless stop: */mᵂ/, */pᵂ/, */ᵐpᵂ/ * no labialized alveolar (nasal or oral) stop: */nᵂ/, */dᵂ/, */ⁿdᵂ/, */tᵂ/, */ⁿtᵂ/ * no labialized voiceless labial, palatal or velar fricative: */fᵂ/, */ᵐfᵂ/, */ʃᵂ/, */ᶮʃᵂ/, */xᵂ/, */ᵑxᵂ/
==== Final consonants ==== Of the 40 consonants found in Medumba, only 7 can be coda consonants: the 3 nasal stops /m, n, ŋ/, the 3 counterpart voiced oral stops /b, d, ɡ/, and the glottal stop /ʔ/. See Table 7 for the list of coda consonants, ordered according to place of articulation (labial, alveolar, velar, glottal), and manner of articulation (nasal stop, oral stop). (16-18) present examples of nasals in coda posit. (19-22) present examples of oral stops in coda position, which display allophonic variation conditioned by the right-edge context. {| class="wikitable mw-collapsible mw-collapsed" ! colspan="7" |Table 7. Final consonants and their allophones |- ! colspan="3" rowspan="2" | ! colspan="4" |Place of Articulation |- !labial !alveolar !velar !glottal |- | rowspan="3" |'''Manner of''' '''Articulation''' | colspan="2" |'''nasal stop''' (n = 3) |m |n |ŋ | |- | rowspan="2" |'''oral stop''' |'''voiced''' (n = 3) |b ~ p |d ~ l |ɡ ~ ʁ/k | |- |'''voiceless''' (n = 1) | | | |ʔ |- | colspan="7" |(adapted from Voorhoeve 1965:328, sn. 3.3.3) |}

==== Initial consonants ==== Table 8 presents the inventory of onset consonants and their allophones. The only consonant excluded from onset position is the glottal stop /ʔ/. All other consonants occur in onset position, so there are 39 possible onset consonnants. In onset position, nasals may be plain ('''C''') or labialized ('''Cᵂ'''). All other consonant types (voiced plosives, voiceless plosives, fricative) occur as plain ('''C'''), labialized ('''Cᵂ'''), pre-nasalized ('''ᴺC'''), or pre-nasalized and labialized ('''ᴺCᵂ'''). In addition, onset consonants display allophonic variation that is conditioned by the following vowel. Examples are given below, as follows: * onset '''labials'''; see (23-29) * onset '''alveolars'''; see (30-38) * onset '''palatals'''; see (39-49) * onset '''velars'''; see (50-59) {| class="wikitable mw-collapsible mw-collapsed" ! colspan="9" |Table 8. === Phonological processes affecting segments ===
==== Vowel insertion ==== Consonant-final words — which are generally CVC because of the size constraint that favours CV or CVC words —are often augmented by a final vowel. This process of vowel insertion happens in one of two contexts: (i) before a pause; (ii) at then end of a sentence. The quality of the inserted vowel is conditioned by the final consonant: if the final C is a glottal stop, then the inserted vowel is schwa; elsewhere, the inserted vowel is a copy of the stem vowel. Examples illustrating vowel insertion are given in xx-yy. {| class="wikitable" |+ |}
(1) a. ''koo'' b. ''cintEE'' ko-o cin-te-e love-FV xx-yy-FV 'to want, to love' 'to urinated' (adapted from Voorhoeve 1965:332)
==== Consonant mutation ==== Consonants in onset position surface with different variants. This consonant allophone, a form of consonant mutation, is conditioned by the following vowel. There are seven conditioning contexts, as follows: # the non-closed vowels # the closed vowels # the high front vowel /i/ # the high non-front vowels /ʉ/ and /u/ # the high central (non-front, non-back) vowel /ʉ/ # the high back vowel /u/ # the vowels /o/ and /ə/ Table 9 lists these seven contexts, along with the set of segments and phonological class that they target, the effect that they have, and the allophonic alternation that they condition. {| class="wikitable mw-collapsible mw-collapsed" ! colspan="6" |Table 9. Conditioning contexts for consonant mutation |- ! colspan="2" |Context !Segment Set !Class !Effect !Alternation |- | rowspan="2" |1. | rowspan="2" |__ V[-Closed] |{b, d, ɟ, g} |voiced stop |"devoicing" |/b/→[p]; /d/→[l]; /ɟ/→[y]; /ɟᵂ/→[yᵂ]; /g/→[ʁ]; /gᵂ/→[w] |- |{ᵐf, ⁿs} |nasalized fricative |voicing |/ᵐf/→[ᵐv]; /ⁿs/→[ⁿz] (except before /o/) |- | rowspan="2" |2. | rowspan="2" |__ V[+Closed] |{t, ⁿt, k, ᵑk} |voiceless stop |aspiration |/t/→[tʰ]; /ⁿt/→[ⁿtʰ]; /k/→[kʰ/kˣ]; /ᵑk/→[ᵑkʰ/ᵑkˣ] |- |{b} |bilabial |devoicing |/b/→[p] (optional) |- |3. |__ /i/ |{ɟ, ɟᵂ, ᶮɟ, ᶮɟᵂ, c, cᵂ} |palatal |fronting + spirantization |/ɟ/→[z]; /ɟᵂ/→[zᵂ]; /ᶮɟ/→[ⁿz]; /ᶮɟᵂ/→[ⁿzᵂ]; /c/ →[ʦ]; /cᵂ/ → [ʦᵂ]; /ᶮcᵂ/ →[ ᶮʃ]? |- | rowspan="2" |4. | rowspan="2" |__ /ʉ, u/ |{ɟ, ᶮɟ, c, cᵂ} |palatal | rowspan="2" |spirantization |/ɟ/ →[ʒ]; /ᶮɟ/ → [ᶮʒ]; /c/ → [cʃ]; /cᵂ/ → [ʃ] (3.1.8, V1965) |- |{gᵂ} |labialized voiced velar |/gᵂ/→[v] |- |5. |__ /ʉ/ |{g, ᵑg} |simplex & nasalized voiced velar |spirantization |/g/ → [ɣ]; /ᵑg/ → [ᵑgˠ] |- |6. |__ /u/ |{g} |simplex voiced velar |retraction + spirantization |/g/ → [ʁ] |- |7. |__ /o, ə/ |{bᵂ} |labialized bilabial |spirantization |/bᵂ/ → [bᵛ] |- | colspan="6" |(adapted from Voorhoeve 1965:xxx-zzz) |} *
== Tone == Medumba is famous for the extent to which tone shapes grammar. Although having only a two-tone contrast, namely High (H) and Low (L), surface tone melodies are conditioned by a variety of lexical, morphological and syntactic factors:
# lexically specified level Low (L) and High (H) tone # morphologically derived falling (HL) and rising (HL) contour tones # syntactically conditioned downstep, where H is produced at a lower pitch than a preceding H tone
=== Two tones: high versus low === Medumba is described as a two-level tone system with low (L) and high (H) tones; examples are given in Table 16. Observe that the L/H contrast is found with all Lexical (open) class categories; this includes verbs, nouns and prepositions. Likewise, Functional (closed-class) categories show an L/H contrasts; this includes verbal F-categories (C, T, and Aspect) and nominal F-categories (Dem, Det, Pl). [Describe examples; also give minimal pairs]
==== Tone contrasts with verbs ==== Verb stems come in two shapes, CV and CVC, with each one contrasting Low and High tone. See (1-5) for examples of High/Low tone contrast with CV stems, and (6-6) for examples of High/Low tone contrast with CVC stems.
